raw_text:
EMI shares hit by profit warning
 
 Shares in music giant EMI have sunk by more than 16% after the firm issued a profit warning following disappointing sales and delays to two album releases.
 
 EMI said music sales for the year to March will fall 8-9% from the year before, with profits set to be 15% lower than analysts had expected. It blamed poor sales since Christmas and delays to the releases of new albums by Coldplay and Gorillaz. By 1200 GMT on Monday, EMI shares were down 16.2% at 235.75 pence.
 
 EMI said two major albums scheduled for release before the end of the financial year in March - one by Coldplay and one by Gorillaz - have now had their release dates put back.
 
 "EMI Music's sales, particularly re-orders, in January have also been lower than anticipated and this is expected to continue through February and March," the company added. "Therefore, for the full year, at constant currency, EMI Music's sales are now expected to be 8% to 9% lower than the prior year." The company said it expected profits to be about £138m ($259.8m). Alain Levy, chairman and chief executive of EMI Music, described the performance as "disappointing", but added that he remained optimistic over future trends in the industry. "The physical music market is showing signs of stabilisation in many parts of the world and digital music, in all its forms, continues to develop at a rapid pace," he said.
 
 Commenting on the delay to the release of the Coldplay and Gorillaz albums, Mr Levy said that "creating and marketing music is not an exact science and cannot always coincide with our reporting periods". "While this rescheduling and recent softness is disappointing, it does not change my views of the improving health of the global recorded music industry," he added. Paul Richards, an analyst at Numis Securities, said the market would be focusing on the slump in music sales rather than the timing of the two albums. "It's unusual to see this much of a downgrade just because of phasing," he said.
llama3.2:1b: EMI shares fell by more than 16% after the company issued a profit warning due to disappointing sales and delays to album releases. Sales for music were expected to be 8-9% lower in the year compared to last year, with profits set to be 15% lower than analysts had predicted.
llama3.2:3b: EMI shares fell 16% after issuing a profit warning due to disappointing sales and delays to Coldplay and Gorillaz album releases, with music sales expected to fall 8-9% and profits set to be 15% lower than expected.
gemma2:2b: EMI Music issued a profit warning due to disappointing sales and delays to new album releases by Coldplay and Gorillaz. Sales are expected to fall 8-9% compared to last year, resulting in lower profits than anticipated.  The company also cited poor January reorders as a factor.  Despite the setback, EMI remains optimistic about the future of the music industry.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points:

- EMI shares have dropped 16.2%.
- EMI released a profit warning after disappointing sales and delays on album releases for Coldplay and Gorillaz.
- Coldplay's upcoming album release is rescheduled, while Gorillaz' is still to be confirmed.
- EMI forecasts profits of £138m ($259.8m) for the full year, but expects them to be 8% to 9% lower than the prior year.
- Alain Levy, chief executive, expressed disappointment with sales, while he remains optimistic about future trends in the music industry.
qwen2.5:1.5b: EMI shares fell by over 16% after issuing a profit warning due to disappointing sales and album release delays, with profits expected to decrease by 8-9%, citing poor Christmas sales and issues with Coldplay and Gorillaz releases. The company also announced that two major albums were delayed in March's financial year, contributing to lower overall revenue projections for the full year.
qwen2.5:3b: EMI shares plummeted by over 16% after issuing a profit warning due to falling music sales and delayed album releases, particularly Coldplay and Gorillaz albums. EMI expects full-year sales to decrease by 8-9% from the previous year at constant currency. Chairman Alain Levy described the performance as disappointing but optimistic about future industry trends. Numis Securities analyst Paul Richards noted that the downgrade was mainly due to timing issues rather than fundamental changes in music sales.
opencoder:1.5b:
EMI shares hit by profit warning

Shares in EMI have sunk by more than 16% after the firm issued a profit warning following disappointing sales and delays to two album releases. EMI reported music sales for the year to March fell 8-9% from the year before, with profits set to be lower than analysts had expected. EMI blamed poor sales since Christmas and delayed the release of new albums by Coldplay and Gorillaz. Following a halt on Monday, EMI shares were down 16.2% at 235.75 pence. The company said it expected profits to be about £138m ($259.8m). Alain Levy described the performance as "disappointing". He added that he remained optimistic over future trends in the industry.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and preserves key ideas and details:

1. EMI shares have sunk by more than 16% after the firm issued a profit warning following disappointing sales and delays to two album releases.
2. EMI shares were down 16.2% at 235.75 pence on Monday, with profits set to be 15% lower than analysts had expected.
3. EMI Music's sales, particularly re-orders, in January have been lower than anticipated and this is expected to continue through February and March. Therefore, for the full year, at constant currency, EMI Music's sales are now expected to be 8% to 9% lower than the prior year.
4. The company expects profits to be about £138m ($259.8m) over the full year. Alain Levy, chairman and chief executive of EMI Music, described the performance as "disappointing", but added that he remained optimistic over future trends in the industry.
5. The delay to the release of the Coldplay and Gorillaz albums has not changed the overall outlook for the music industry, but it does highlight the challenges faced by record labels in today's market.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text about EMI shares and their performance after hitting a profit warning. First, I'll read through each paragraph carefully.

The first part talks about EMI's share price dropping by over 16%. They mentioned that this was due to disappointing sales and delays in releasing two albums. The market expects a 8-9% drop in sales and profits of around £138m. They also mentioned specific sales projections for the year, with the main albums now rescheduled.

I should make sure to highlight the key points: the share price drop, reasons (sales, delays), expected sales and profit decreases, the specific albums being rescheduled, and Mr. Levy's comments about the market trends and his own optimism.

Also, some important phrases are mentioned by Mr. Levy, like "reorders" and digital music growth. The analysts' reaction to the delay is neutral, focusing on sales rather than timing. There's a mention of Paul Richards suggesting a different focus.

I need to keep everything concise without adding any explanations or formatting. Just the summary in plain text.
</think>

EMI shares have dropped by over 16%, driven by disappointing sales and delays in releasing two albums. The company expects sales to fall 8-9% and profits to be 15% lower than expected, with specific sales projections for the year including a decline in reorders since Christmas. Coldplay and Gorillaz's albums are now rescheduled before March. EMI CEO Alain Levy noted physical sales will continue to be lower than anticipated, expecting a 8-9% drop in sales and profits rising faster during the financial year. Mr. Levy remained optimistic about industry trends but acknowledged the disappointing timing of the album releases. Analysts saw limited impact on the market focusing more on music sales than release dates.
tinyllama:1.1b: EMI, one of Europe's leading music companies, has reported a sharp fall in profits as it suffered disappointing sales and delays to two albums relieving sales since the Christmas period, resulting in a decrease in earnings of more than 16%. The company also blamed poor sales of major releases by Coldplay and Gorillaz for its performance in the financial year. In response to these setbacks, EMI announced that it would be delaying the release dates of two upcoming albums, while CEO Alain Levy remained optimistic about the future performance of the industry. Despite the setbacks, Mr. Levy attributed the decline in music sales primarily to "improving health" of the global recorded music industry, which was still expected to grow at a steady pace over the next year or so. The market focus would be on the delay in the release dates of the two albums, rather than the timing of these releases themselves.
tinydolphin:1.1b: EMI shares dropped more than 16% after the company issued a profit warning due to disappointing sales and delays in releasing albums by Coldplay and Gorillaz. The music industry has been witnessing an increasingly competitive landscape with major players like Apple, Spotify, and Warner Music all trying to expand their market share. Despite facing headwinds from the pandemic, EMI managed to achieve a 15% lower profit than analysts had expected. However, it was not able to provide specific revenue or earnings estimates for the full year due to the reschuling of Coldplay and Gorillaz' album releases. The stock market is closely watching the health of the global recorded music industry amidst this shifting landscape.
phi:2.7b: EMI's shares dropped 16.2% after issuing a profit warning due to poor album sales and delays in releasing new albums by Coldplay and Gorillaz, which were set back until March. The company expects music sales for the year to fall 8-9%, with profits 15% lower than expected. Alain Levy, EMI's CEO, remains optimistic about future industry trends despite the disappointing performance.
orca-mini:3b: EMI shares dropped by 16.2% after the company issued a profit warning due to poor sales since Christmas and delays to two album releases, blaming music sales for the year ending March for falling 8-9% from the previous year and profits being 15% lower than analysts had expected. Two major albums scheduled for release before the end of the financial year in March have now been delayed, although the company remains optimistic about future trends in the industry despite the delay.
hermes3:3b: EMI shares fall over 16% due to 8-9% drop in yearly music sales and 15% lower than expected profits, caused by poor Christmas sales and delays for Coldplay and Gorillaz album releases.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: EMI shares dropped by 16% due to a profit warning issued after disappointing sales and delays to album releases from Coldplay and Gorillaz. EMI Music's sales are expected to fall 8-9% for the year, with profits set to be 15% lower than analysts' expectations. The company cited poor sales since Christmas and delays in album releases as the reason for the lower sales and profits. Despite the disappointing performance, Alain Levy, EMI Music's chairman, remained optimistic about future trends in the industry, citing signs of stabilization in the physical music market and rapid development of digital music.

Despite the setback, EMI's chairman Alain Levy remained optimistic about the industry's future, noting signs of market stabilization and digital music growth. Analysts, however, focused on the broader decline in music sales rather than the album delays.

Music sales for Q1 2011 will be lower by 8%-9%, with poor Christmas sales and release date changes attributed to the decrease. EMI expects £3-4 million ($4-5.6 million) in profits, while its music sales are now anticipated to be 8% to 9% lower for the year. Alain Levy remains optimistic about the future of the industry, noting signs of stabilisation in the physical music market and rapid growth in digital music consumption.
granite3.1-dense:2b: EMI shares plummeted by over 16% following a profit warning due to disappointing sales and delays in releasing Coldplay and Gorillaz albums. These shortfalls are attributed to subpar sales since Christmas and the delays in the two major album releases. Despite this setback, EMI's CEO remains optimistic about industry trends, noting stabilization in parts of the physical music market and rapid growth in digital music. Analyst Paul Richards from Numis Securities highlighted that investors will primarily focus on the decline in music sales rather than the album delays.
